text:
Hey folks! Do any of you have experience running *content marketing internship programmes in your companies?* 

Some context: the jobs listed here on Superpath and elsewhere are awesome, but I feel like there is too huge a gap between early-stage marketers looking for an opportunity and companies willing to train & grow them.

I’ve been thinking that, as someone in a senior position with a budget and decision-making power, I have a ‘duty’ to start opening a few doors, and an internship programme seems like it could be a good way to do it. Or maybe I’m wrong? I’d love to hear your thoughts on this. :heart:

elements.text: Hey folks! Do any of you have experience running

I’ve been thinking that, as someone in a senior position with a budget and decision-making power, I have a ‘duty’ to start opening a few doors, and an internship programme seems like it could be a good way to do it. Or maybe I’m wrong? I’d love to hear your thoughts on this.

text: I got my start in content marketing via internships, so I definitely think it's a great idea! Happy to share my perspective as a past intern if you'd like to know what I think worked / didn't work. <@URAV154AV> was the one leading the program when I was there so she might also have some insights from the management perspective.

was the one leading the program when I was there so she might also have some insights from the management perspective.

text: Yes please! I’ll DM you later today/tomorrow :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yes please! I’ll DM you later today/tomorrow

text:
This is a great idea. I think I would think through what would add the most value to someone just starting out. Marketing is so broad it makes it tough. If we look at job postings, what is something that most employers look for that someone just out of school would not have?

One idea off the top of my head - I look for people that have experience using social media scheduling softwares, Slack, Zoom, and PM softwares. Something even as basic as that we sometimes take for granted when we’re more experienced and have been using them for a long time. And to be fair, I learned it in a workplace. Having a chance to practice and learn with real tools helps.

Also - giving and receiving feedback in real offices with real people. Hone those soft skills and prevent bouts of imposter syndrome when a future CEO hacks and slashes every design and piece of copy in a campaign. Or asks for “more pizzazz.” Or to make the logo bigger. Or for snackable content. Or answers on email open rates.  :exploding_head: :face_with_head_bandage: :woozy_face:

Well done for taking this on!

text: I have not started or managed a program but I do love it as a way to provide opportunity and training, and to build talent pipeline. I would second Kayla’s thoughtful recommendations and the idea of thinking about skills we might take for granted. With true entry-level employees/interns, a strong opportunity will also help them with developing workplace communication skills (e.g. how to write a good email), time management and prioritization, planning and completing small projects, etc. Even just experiencing workplace norms adds value and a foundation for their future roles, perhaps even moreso now that many teams are remote or hybrid which might not be the type of work they had prepared for.

text:
Hey everyone! *Curious if anyone works with a mentor/coach and has any tips on finding the right one?* 

When I joined TokyWoky, we were pre-PMF and almost at 0 rev, now where almost at 2M ARR and I'm growing the marketing team. My role is changing and there's a lot more need for me to become strategic rather than purely focus on the operational side of things.

Ideally I'm looking for a coach to help me upskill in strategy, positioning, and the more big picture stuff. Obviously paid but unsure what the ongoing rates are.

I'm getting a lot of value from communities such as these, but I'm looking for something more personalized and in-depth.

text: Alicia and Kayla, THANK YOU so much for sharing your point of view. You both spoke of different skills we take for granted, which I frankly had not thought about—_at all!_ It makes so much sense, and I am even more excited about this than I was before! :clap:

at all!

text:
Hey Hanne! My partner does leadership coaching, but leans more on the side of people management + career development. I can send you a link to her site if you're interested.

Tips wise, I think a lot of it comes down to finding personality fit. If you're going to be working 1:1 with someone for a while, and getting into personalized (and personal!) stuff... it's probably going to get intense, and emotional too. You'll want someone you feel quite comfy with. I dunno how else you can really find that fit without doing initial meetups/interviews! And in today's day n age, in-person vs remote coaching can be a huge variable too. Even if a coach comes highly recommended, if they can't do in-person and that's what you really need... well, then it's not a good fit :)

text:
Hey everyone, I recently discovered a mutual connection on LinkedIn *copied some of my website copy and used it for their own portfolio*. I'm a copywriter and content strategist, so the way I market myself as a writer is key to getting clients.

I'd like to write an email to this person and request they take down the flagrantly similar copy. Do I have recourse? Has anyone gone through something similar? They recently have been employed at an agency I admire and would love to freelance for in the future, so I want to be cognizant of that. Any help is appreciated!

elements.text: Hey everyone, I recently discovered a mutual connection on LinkedIn
copied some of my website copy and used it for their own portfolio

. I'm a copywriter and content strategist, so the way I market myself as a writer is key to getting clients.

I'd like to write an email to this person and request they take down the flagrantly similar copy. Do I have recourse? Has anyone gone through something similar? They recently have been employed at an agency I admire and would love to freelance for in the future, so I want to be cognizant of that. Any help is appreciated!

text: Don't have any real legal advice here, but the Way Back Machine on Archive can probably help prove that she lifted your copy. Hopefully there's a record there. Best of luck!

elements.text: Don't have any real legal advice here, but the Way Back Machine on Archive can probably help prove that she lifted your copy. Hopefully there's a record there. Best of luck!

text: Yes! I have documentation/screenshots of my portfolio within my website editor dating back to 2018 with the particular section that was plagiarized, so there is proof

elements.text: Yes! I have documentation/screenshots of my portfolio within my website editor dating back to 2018 with the particular section that was plagiarized, so there is proof

text:
I’m a huge fan of (paid) internships and have seen a number of amazing marketers like <@ULJBEFSJJ> get their start through some of the internship programs I’ve run at two different companies.

The program that Tatiana was hired through was an org-wide partnership with a local university co-op program and some of the costs were sometimes offset by government wage subsidies (in Canada). I’ve also hired people into internships through more generic hiring processes.

If I was going to do it again, I would 100% go through a university/college co-op program because they produce work-ready students. The students may not have known everything about marketing, but they did know overall work etiquette and were highly motivated to get experience, get a good performance evaluation, and make money. I don’t think we ever hired a “dud” through that program. It was hit or miss hiring people from a wider talent pool.

My advice is definitely to create a dedicated “role” with responsibilities (either ongoing or project-based for the duration of the internship) and the qualities you’re looking for to be able to meet those responsibilities. DO NOT just create an “internship” role where whoever you hire is supposed to take on all the work that nobody else wants to do. If you’re being this thoughtful about it, you probably wouldn’t do that anyway, but when internship programs or terms fail, it’s usually due to this lack of role definition and/or poor onboarding. Whatever onboarding and management you would do for a full-time, permanent employee, times it by 2 or 3 per intern. It can be a lot of work, but it’s also incredibly rewarding and I would say some of the best work our teams did was with the help of interns.

text:
Hi <@U02CJS7K6GZ>. This is such an important discussion.

I had a very similar situation and I struggled to find the right coach, I interviewed many, and at the end of the day not a single one of them had done more than one thing on my list of goals.
(write a book, scale my team, scale my processes, make earnings publicly speaking etc.) I loved my time with the coach I eventually chose, but if I had to do it again I would have kept looking. I guess what I’m saying is I have NO idea how to find the right fit. Good luck and keep me posted - I will want a coach again, it’s something I try to do yearly at least for part of the year (because it also costs so much). Next time I really want to find out that can help me with more advanced PM, scaling, process building, and who has the connections to help me make some strides in a few areas. Again, my coach was lovely and I liked her a lot, it just wasn’t quite right and looking at her curriculum/plans I should have known that.

Since you mentioned the going rate, I don’t mind sharing what I paid. My last one cost me 5k for 90 days. :money_mouth_face: :grimacing:

Good luck and keep me posted - I will want a coach again, it’s something I try to do yearly at least for part of the year (because it also costs so much). Next time I really want to find out that can help me with more advanced PM, scaling, process building, and who has the connections to help me make some strides in a few areas. Again, my coach was lovely and I liked her a lot, it just wasn’t quite right and looking at her curriculum/plans I should have known that.

Since you mentioned the going rate, I don’t mind sharing what I paid. My last one cost me 5k for 90 days.

Bonus if it's a wellness agency or someone has wellness clients.
